The process of improvement - why some pain?

06 Oct 2022 by Josh

Consciousness by knowledge

In this longer article on the disappointing reactions to the Depp v. Heard trial in Virginia a therapist‚Äôs explanation of the process of change is related (the writer having heard it secondhand).

Not conscious of one's (in)competenceConscious of one's (in)competence
Incompetent1) Unconscious incompetence ‚û°Ô∏è2) Conscious incompetence ‚¨áÔ∏è
Competent4) Unconscious competence üèÜ‚¨ÖÔ∏è 3) Conscious competence

As the emoji arrows and trophy at the end illustrate; if change is seen as a journey from 1: Unconscious incompetence to the prize of 4: Unconscious competence - then, hinted by the red and yellow background it means passing through some less than comfortable states: conscious incompetence (which may have people having to grapple with shame), and conscious competence (better than incompetence but more burdensome that an unconscious state).

General case

The grid is obviously a similar concept to any logical explanation of Donald Rumsfeld‚Äôs much reported known knowns and unknown unknowns remarks

Not aware of your knowledgeAware of your knowledge
Do not have the knowledgeUnknown unknowns (places where your ignorance can unexpectedly bite you)Known unknowns (you know you don't know this but are at least aware and can plan with that in mind)
Have the knowledgeUnknown knowns (probably things you can work out from stuff you know or stuff you have known about yet consciously don't recall knowing)Known knowns (stuff you know and are aware of knowing it - you know you are knowledgeable in this area)

However unless studying for an exam or suffering mental degradation this general case grid, applied generally, is not so emotion laden - as the mere fact of knowing something is usually not very emotion laden. Feeling you will fail your exam or that your mind is going is liable to stir emotion. While on the other hand experienced people in many professions accept that they need reference works - they know more and different things than novices - but they do not know all professional knowledge off the top of their head - the state of not knowing does not have to provoke lots of emotion.
